info-panel.title: Welcome to The Scale of the Universe VR
info-panel.detail:
Left grip will zoom in.  Right grip to zoom out.

Point and click at an object to learn more about it.

Left thumbstick to move forwards, backwards left and right.

Right thumbstick to turn left or right, and move up or down.

Based on a concept by Cary Huang.

milkyway.title: The Milky Way
milkyway.detail:
The Milky Way is the galaxy that we live in.

It measures about 100,000 light year across, and is estimated to contain several hundred billion stars, of which our sun is just one.

The Milky Way is just one of an estimated two trillion galaxies within the observable universe.
milkyway.credit: Image courtesy NASA / JPL-Caltech / R.Hurt (SSC Caltech).

sun.title: The Sun
sun.detail:
The Sun is our nearest star.  Its diameter is about 1.39 million km, and it is 151.7 million km from Earth - a distance known as 1 A.U. (Astronomical Unit).

Although from Earth it looks far larger than any other star, it is in fact fairly average, as stars go.

The Sun is roughly in the middle of its lifecycle.  It has existed for about 4.6 billion years, and will die in about 5.5 billion years' time.

jupiter.title: Jupiter
jupiter.detail:
Jupiter is the largest planet in our Solar System.

It has a diameter of 139,820km (10% of the diameter of the sun), meaning that it is more than 1300 times bigger than Earth in volume.

However it is much less dense than Earth, so only has 318 times the mass of Earth.
jupiter.credit: 3D model by Mieke Roth via Sketchfab.

earth.title: Earth
earth.detail:
Earth is the third planet orbiting an unremarkable star, in an unremarkable part of an unremarkable galaxy.

However it is notable for being the only planet that we know of that harbours life.

Scientists have even found some evidence of intelligent lifeforms living on this planet.

Earth has a diameter of 12,742 km.
earth.credit: 3D model by Alan Zimmerman via Sketchfab.

moon.title: The Moon
moon.detail:
Lots of planets have moons, but when we say 'The Moon' we are usually referring to the Earth's moon.

The diameter of the moon is 3,475km, which is less than a third of the diameter of Earth.

The moon is tidally locked to Earth, meaning that on Earth we always see the same side of the moon.

In reality the moon is actually 20 times further from Earth than you see in this simulation, at a distance of 384,400km.

deimos.title: Deimos
deimos.detail:
Deimos is the smaller, and outermost, of Mars's two moons.

It is a small moon, only about 12km across, and orbits Mars every 30.3 hours, at a distance of 23,500km.

elcapitan.title: El Capitan
elcapitan.detail:
El Capitan is a vertical rock formation in Yosemite National Park, in California.

The granite cliff is 914m from bottom to top, and is a popular challenge with rock climbers.
elcapitan.credit: 3D model by Mark Burginger architect via Sketchfab.

eiffel.title: The Eiffel Tower
eiffel.detail:
The Eiffel Tower was built in Paris, France in 1889 to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the French Revolution.

It is 324m tall (to the top of the spire).

trex.title: Tyrannosaurus Rex
trex.detail:
Tyrannosaurus Rex was the largest land predator ever to walk the earth.

Fully grown adults could measure 12-13m in length, and weighed between 9 and 14 tons.

Tyrannosaurus became extinct 65 million years ago, when an asteroid struck the earth, leading to a mass extinction event.

chicken.title: Chicken
chicken.detail:
The chicken is a domesticated bird.  They are commonly kept for egg production, and also eaten as meat.

There are 26 billion chickens in the world: more than 3 times as many as there are humans.

ant.title: Ant
ant.detail:
The ant is a small insect that lives in highly organized large societies.

There are many species of ant, and they vary greatly in size, from species that are less than a millimeter, to species that are over 50mm in length.

This model shows a typical common ant, about 6mm in length.

cell.title: Animal Cell
cell.detail:
This is a model of a typical animal cell.

The colors are used to highlight the different elements of the cell - they are not realistic.

A typical animal cell is 10-20 micrometers in diameter.
cell.credit: 3D model by Lauri Purhonen via Sketchfab.

virus.title: Coronavirus
virus.detail:
This is the SARS-CoV-2 virus that caused the COVID-19 pandemic, which began in 2020.

The virus is approximately 100 nanometers in diameter.

The red spikes on the virus are the infamous 'spike proteins', which it uses to attack cells.

glucose.title: Glucose molecule
glucose.detail:
Glucose is the simplest, and most common, form of sugar.

This is a model of a single molecule of glucose.

Glucose has the molecular formula C6H12O6.

In this model, carbon atoms are black, oxygen atoms are red, and hydrogen atoms are white.

A single molecule is approximately 1.5 nanometers across.
